proof.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: facts, information, documents etc that prove something is true
proof.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: proof of the existence of life on other planets
This latest interview was further proof of how good at her job Cara was.
Do you have any proof that this man stole your bag?
There is no proof that the document is authentic.
proof.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a copy of a piece of writing or a photograph that is checked carefully before the final printing is done
proof.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a test in mathematics of whether a calculation is correct
proof.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a list of reasons that shows a theorem (=statement) in geometry to be true
proof.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a measurement of the strength of some types of alcoholic drink, especially spirits
proof.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: 70% proof vodka  (=that contains 70% pure alcohol) British English
70 proof vodka  (=that contains 35% pure alcohol) American English
proof.translation[0].note_box[0].section: have proof
The newspaper claimed it had proof that I worked for the CIA.
provide/give proof
You will be required to provide proof of your identity.
need proof
He needed proof to back up those allegations.
there is proof
There is now proof that giant squid do exist.
further proof
He showed his driving licence as further proof of his identity.
scientific proof
They say they have scientific proof that the treatment works.
living proof
She is living proof that stress need not necessarily be ageing.
clear proof
His indecision is clear proof of his inability to handle the situation.
conclusive/tangible proof
There is no conclusive proof that your son is dead.
proof of identity
Do you have any proof of identity, such as a passport?
proof of purchase
We will give a refund only if proof of purchase is provided.
proof of ownership
Take photos of anything unusual you own as proof of ownership.
proof positive
Here is proof positive that she's wrong.
the burden/onus of proof
The burden of proof is on the prosecution.
proof.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to treat a material with a substance in order to protect it against water, oil etc
proof.translation[2].definitions[0].note: Proof is usually passive in this meaning
proof.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Do you want me to proof those documents for you?
proof.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: used to describe something which a particular thing cannot harm or pass through, or which protects people against that thing
proof.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: an ovenproof dish  (=that cannot be harmed by heat)
proof.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: used to describe something which cannot easily be affected or damaged by someone or something
proof.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: to treat or make something so that a particular thing cannot harm it or pass through it, or so that it gives protection against it
proof.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: soundproof a room  (=so that sound cannot get into or out of it)
